thread.title: LGBT Dance Party/Protest Targets Vice-President Elect Pence
thread.title_full: LGBT Dance Party/Protest Targets Vice-President Elect Pence

author: Fred Maxwell
title: LGBT Dance Party/Protest Targets Vice-President Elect Pence
text:
LGBT Dance Party/Protest Targets Vice-President Elect Pence "... leave a mark that Mike Pence will never forget.” by Fred Maxwell January 19, 2017 at 1:35pm 
Everybody enjoys a party. Right? 
Maybe not, especially if the party is going on outside of your house. 
When activists from the LGBT community launched a “queer dance party” in the neighborhood of Mike Pence’s temporary Washington D.C. residence on Wednesday to protest his stance on homosexuality, the vice-president-elect was invited to “Come dance, Daddy Pence.” Advertisement - story continues below 
— remmagolds (@rg0lds) January 19, 2017 
Much of the protest was captured on video and posted to Twitter. Dance protest has arrived – now dancing a half a block from Mike Pence's rental house. Were chanting "Daddy Pence, come dance" pic.twitter.com/kaUEbUXxAC 
— Betsy Klein (@betsy_klein) January 19, 2017 Advertisement - story continues below Queer dance party is heading over to Mike Pence's house to dance their butts off #wearehereandwewilldance #disruptj20 pic.twitter.com/Y0EK8rlI99 
— remmagolds (@rg0lds) January 18, 2017 
Approximately 200 individuals were on hand to participate in the protest, which lasted about two and a half hours. 
If the protesters were hoping to catch a glimpse of Pence, they were disappointed, however. The vice-president-elect and his wife were away from their home when the protest took place. 
Protest organizer Firas Nasr told the Washington Post said the dance party was organized to educate Pence on the LGBT community. Advertisement - story continues below Former ‘Apprentice’ Contestant Files Defamation Suit Against Trump 
“Dance is so integral to the queer community as a form of self-expression and a form of asserting our power and our beauty and our love for one another.” Nasr said. “The idea is to leave a mark that Mike Pence will never forget.” 
He went on to say he wanted Pence to realize the LGBT community is a “united queer community.” 
Some residents of the neighborhood were on hand to watch the dancing. At least two of those residents said they were not upset by the commotion. 
Mary Ann Carmody told the Washington Post, “I love this. I love the world. It’s wonderful to see people on the street like this. We’re lucky we can do this.” 
Joanna Pratt, a longtime resident of the neighborhood said, “We come in all shapes, sizes, colors, beliefs, and we need to respect our diversity.” 
“The LGBT community has had a real struggle to be respected and be accepted, and that’s a sad statement on our country and our culture that they’ve had that struggle,” she added. What do you think? Scroll down to comment below. Advertisement Popular Right Now
